Masih Dikandangkan, Kapan Boeing 737 MAX 8 Bisa Terbang Lagi?
01 Nov 2019, 04:50 by Herdi Alif Alhikam


Foto: REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson

Jakarta - Pesawat Boeing 737 MAX 8 dikandangkan pasca dua kecelakaan besar dalam sebulan tercatat Oktober tahun lalu menimpa pesawat ini, yaitu Ethiopian Airline dan Lion Air.Usai kejadian tersebut ramai-ramai otoritas penerbangan seluruh dunia pun 'mengandangkan' alias melakukan grounded pada pesawat MAX 8. Tak terkecuali di Indonesia, sejak Maret lalu penangguhan terbang telah dilakukan.Lantas apakah Boeing 737 MAX 8 masih bisa mengudara kembali?Menurut Direktur Jenderal Perhubungan Udara Kemenhub Polana B Pramesti pemerintah hingga kini masih menunggu hasil sertifikasi airworthines directive dari pihak Otoritas Penerbangan Amerika (Federal Aviation Administration/FAA) untuk Boeing 737 MAX 8, khususnya untuk sensor Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) yang dipasang di pesawat MAX 8."Iya kita tetap akan menunggu dari FAA, itu salah satu yang bikin building the trust kalau pesawat (MAX 8) mau diterbangkan kembali," ucap Polana di Kantor DKPPU, Bandara Soetta, Jumat (1/11/2019).Polana selain sertifikasi dari FAA, beberapa otoritas penerbangan sipil negara lain pun akan melakukan sertifikasi. Kemungkinan, pihaknya juga akan memperhatikan hal itu saat mengambil keputusan sebagai pertimbangan tambahan.Dia menyebutkan bahwa, Transport Canada dari Kanada, The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) dari Uni Eropa, National Civil Aviation Agency (ANAC) dari Brazil, dan Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) dari China mau melakukan sertifikasi juga."Setelah sertifikasi FAA, ada badan otoritas penerbangan yang akan lakukan sertifikasi ulang. Kami akan lihat hasil mereka juga, kami akan menunggu meski belum tahu kapan keluarnya," kata Polana.Polana juga menyebut nasib MAX 8 juga sesuai dengan otoritas bandara se-Asean. Dia menyatakan hingga kini masih berdiskusi dan komunikasi rutin dengan negara-negara tetangga soal penggunaan Boeing 737 MAX 8."Kerja sama terus kami galangkan bersama otoritas penerbangan sipil di negara se-ASEAN," ucap Polana.Hingga kini ada 11 pesawat MAX 8 yang dikandangkan di Indonesia. 10 di antaranya milik Lion Air, satu pesawat milik Garuda Indonesia. When it is still grounded, when will the Boeing 737 MAX 8 be able to fly again?
01 Nov 2019, 04:50 by Herdi Alif Alhikam


Photo: REUTERS / Lindsey Wasson

Jakarta - Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft was grounded after two major accidents in the month of October last year befell this aircraft, namely Ethiopian Airline and Lion Air.Usai the incident was crowded the aviation authorities around the world were 'grounded' alias to grounded on MAX 8 aircraft No exception in Indonesia, since last March the suspension of flying has been carried out. Then is the Boeing 737 MAX 8 still able to air again? According to the Director General of Air Transportation of the Ministry of Transportation Polana B Pramesti government is still waiting for the results of the airworthines directive certification from the American Aviation Authority Aviation Administration / FAA) for the Boeing 737 MAX 8, specifically for the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) sensor installed on the MAX 8. "Yes, we will continue to wait from the FAA, it is one that makes building the trust if the aircraft (MAX 8) ) want to be flown back, "said Polana at the DKPPU Office, Soetta Airport, Friday (1 / 11/2019).Polana other than certification from the FAA, several civil aviation authorities in other countries will also carry out certification. Likely, it will also pay attention to that when taking decisions as an additional consideration. He mentioned that, Transport Canada from Canada, The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) from the European Union, National Civil Aviation Agency (ANAC) from Brazil, and Civil Aviation The Administration of China (CAAC) from China wants to do the certification too. "After FAA certification, there are aviation authority bodies that will do recertification. We will see their results as well, we will wait even though we don't know when it will come out," said Polana. said the fate of MAX 8 is also in accordance with the authority of ASEAN airports. He stated that up to now still having regular discussions and communication with neighboring countries regarding the use of the Boeing 737 MAX 8. "We continue to build cooperation with civil aviation authorities in ASEAN countries," said Polana. Until now there are 11 MAX 8 aircraft that are grounded in Indonesia. 10 of them belonged to Lion Air, a plane owned by Garuda Indonesia.
